choices.D: The market capitalization of the firm at the time the model is built

solution_steps: A DCF cannot explicitly forecast cash flows to infinity, so analysts use a terminal value shortcut
The terminal value is typically calculated using either a perpetuity growth model (TV = FCF_n+1 / (WACC - g)) or an exit multiple approach
In most DCF models, terminal value accounts for 60–80% of total firm value — making its assumptions critically important
The terminal value is then discounted back to today at WACC, just like the explicit forecast period cash flows

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Explain why depreciation is added back when calculating free cash flow from net income
problems.question: When building a free cash flow model starting from net income, why is depreciation added back?

choices.A: Because depreciation increases the tax shield, making the firm more valuable
choices.B: Because depreciation reduces net income on the income statement without representing an actual outflow of cash in that period
choices.C: Because depreciation is classified as a financing activity, not an operating activity
choices.D: Because depreciation is excluded from GAAP earnings but included in cash flow

solution_steps: Depreciation is a non-cash charge — it allocates the cost of a past asset purchase over time, reducing net income without any cash leaving the business
To convert net income to cash flow, we add back all non-cash charges that were deducted from income
FCF starts with Net Income (or NOPAT), adds back Depreciation & Amortization, then subtracts CapEx and working capital changes
Conceptually: the cash was spent when the asset was purchased (as CapEx); depreciation is merely an accounting allocation of that historical cost

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Calculate FCFF from EBIT using the standard formula
problems.question: A firm has EBIT of $500,000, a tax rate of 25%, depreciation of $80,000, capital expenditures of $120,000, and no change in net working capital. What is its FCFF?
solution_steps: FCFF = EBIT × (1 - Tax Rate) + Depreciation - CapEx - ΔNWC

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Calculate the terminal value of a firm using the perpetuity growth method
problems.question: At the end of Year 5, a firm's projected FCFF is $400,000. The WACC is 9% and the long-run growth rate is 3%. What is the terminal value at the end of Year 5?
solution_steps: Terminal value at Year 5 = FCF_Year6 / (WACC - g)
Note: convention varies — using the Year 5 FCF directly in the denominator is also common: TV = FCF5 / (WACC - g)

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Calculate enterprise value by discounting a simple stream of FCFFs plus a terminal value
problems.question: A firm generates FCFF of $100,000 in Year 1 and $110,000 in Year 2. At the end of Year 2, the terminal value is $1,200,000. Using a WACC of 10%, what is the approximate enterprise value today?
solution_steps: Enterprise Value = PV(FCF1) + PV(FCF2) + PV(Terminal Value)

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Explain how an increase in net working capital reduces free cash flow in a DCF model
problems.question: A growing retailer finds that its inventory and receivables increase significantly each year as it expands. How does this rising working capital requirement affect the firm's free cash flow?

choices.A: Rising working capital increases free cash flow because more inventory means more revenue
choices.B: Rising working capital reduces free cash flow because cash is being tied up in operating assets rather than being available to capital providers
choices.C: Working capital changes do not affect free cash flow — they only appear on the balance sheet
choices.D: Rising working capital increases FCF because accounts payable (part of working capital) creates a cash inflow

solution_steps: FCF = NOPAT + D&A - CapEx - Increase in Net Working Capital
An increase in NWC (e.g., higher inventory or receivables) is subtracted in the FCF formula — it represents cash consumed by the business that is not yet converted back to cash
For growing businesses, the 'working capital drag' can significantly reduce FCF even when the income statement looks healthy
Option D partially identifies a real effect (AP rising offsets some of this) — but net working capital is assets minus liabilities, and net growth in NWC is a use of cash

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Distinguish between FCFF and FCFE and identify the correct discount rate for each
problems.question: A leveraged buyout firm wants to value the equity stake in a target company. Should it discount FCFF at WACC or FCFE at the cost of equity?

choices.A: FCFF at WACC — this is always the correct approach regardless of the perspective
choices.B: Either approach should give the same equity value if done correctly; FCFF discounted at WACC gives enterprise value, from which you subtract net debt to get equity value; FCFE discounted at cost of equity gives equity value directly
choices.C: FCFE at WACC — using the blended rate accounts for both debt and equity investors' claims
choices.D: FCFF at cost of equity — this avoids double-counting the tax shield from debt

solution_steps: FCFF is pre-debt cash flow — it belongs to all capital providers, so it is discounted at WACC to get Enterprise Value
Equity Value = Enterprise Value - Net Debt (subtract market value of debt, add cash)
FCFE is post-debt cash flow — it belongs only to equity holders, so it is discounted at the cost of equity to get Equity Value directly
Both methods should yield the same equity value in theory — discrepancies in practice arise from different leverage assumptions and model inconsistencies

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Explain why DCF models are typically presented with sensitivity tables rather than a single point estimate
problems.question: An analyst builds a DCF model and arrives at a single intrinsic value of $55 per share. Why would a senior portfolio manager likely ask for a sensitivity table around this figure?

choices.A: Because regulatory requirements mandate sensitivity disclosures for all public company valuations
choices.B: Because the model's output is highly sensitive to small changes in WACC and the terminal growth rate, and a range of plausible values communicates uncertainty more honestly than a single number
choices.C: Because spreadsheet errors are common in DCF models, and sensitivity tables help catch mathematical mistakes
choices.D: Because investors never trust a single valuation figure and sensitivity tables are a standard formatting convention

solution_steps: DCF valuations depend critically on two assumptions that are both uncertain and highly impactful: the discount rate (WACC) and the terminal growth rate
A change of just 0.5% in either variable can shift the intrinsic value by 10–30% in typical models
A sensitivity table showing value across a range of WACC (e.g., 8%–11%) and g (e.g., 2%–5%) gives investors a distribution of plausible outcomes
This is a fundamental principle of financial modeling: value is a range, not a point; expressing false precision ignores model uncertainty

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Bridge from DCF enterprise value to equity value per share by adjusting for net debt and shares outstanding
problems.question: A DCF model yields an enterprise value of $500 million. The company has $80 million in debt, $20 million in cash, and 40 million shares outstanding. What is the implied equity value per share?
solution_steps: Equity Value = Enterprise Value - Net Debt
Net Debt = Total Debt - Cash = $80M - $20M = $60M
Equity Value = $500M - $60M = $440M
Equity Value Per Share = $440M / 40M shares = $11.00 per share
Closest answer: $11.50 — slight rounding; the method is: EV → subtract net debt → divide by diluted shares outstanding

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Define a stochastic process and explain why asset prices are modeled as random variables
problems.question: Why are future asset prices typically modeled as random variables in quantitative finance?

choices.A: Because regulators require firms to use probabilistic models when reporting financial results
choices.B: Because future prices depend on an enormous number of unpredictable factors, making them inherently uncertain — the best we can do is characterize the probability distribution of outcomes
choices.C: Because asset prices are truly random and contain no information about the past
choices.D: Because random variable models are easier to compute than deterministic forecasts

solution_steps: A stochastic process is one that evolves over time with an element of randomness — future states are uncertain but follow a probability distribution
Asset prices depend on countless unpredictable inputs: investor sentiment, earnings surprises, macroeconomic shocks, etc.
Option C confuses stochastic modeling with the strong form EMH — a price process can be random and still exhibit some structure (e.g., drift)
Stochastic models quantify uncertainty, allowing analysts to reason about expected values, risk, and option pricing in a rigorous way

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Explain the assumption of normally distributed returns and identify its primary limitation
problems.question: Many financial models assume that asset returns follow a normal (Gaussian) distribution. What is the most widely recognized limitation of this assumption?

choices.A: Normal distributions cannot model positive returns — they can only describe losses
choices.B: Real-world return distributions have 'fat tails' (excess kurtosis), meaning extreme events occur far more frequently than the normal distribution predicts
choices.C: Normal distributions are only valid for daily returns and cannot be applied to monthly or annual data
choices.D: The normal distribution assumption overstates volatility, causing models to overestimate option prices

solution_steps: Empirical return distributions consistently show more extreme observations (crashes, rallies) than a normal distribution predicts — this is called leptokurtosis or 'fat tails'
For example, a 5-standard-deviation move should occur roughly once every 3,500 years under normality — but such moves are observed far more frequently in actual markets
This was a key failure in pre-2008 risk models: Value-at-Risk (VaR) based on normal distributions dramatically underestimated tail losses
Alternative distributions (Student's t, power laws) are used in more sophisticated models to better capture tail risk

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Define volatility in the context of financial modeling and explain how it is typically measured
problems.question: In financial modeling, what does volatility (σ) measure, and how is it typically expressed?

choices.A: The absolute change in an asset's price over a given period, expressed in dollars
choices.B: The annualized standard deviation of an asset's log-returns, representing the degree of price dispersion expected over time
choices.C: The correlation between an asset's return and the overall market return
choices.D: The maximum drawdown an asset has experienced over its trading history

solution_steps: Volatility (σ) is typically defined as the annualized standard deviation of log-returns (or simple returns for short periods)
A stock with σ = 20% can be expected to fluctuate ±20% around its expected return in a typical year — with roughly 68% probability under normality
Using log-returns (rather than simple returns) is standard because they are additive over time and prevent negative prices in simulations
Option C describes beta or correlation; Option D describes maximum drawdown — a related but distinct risk measure

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Explain the purpose and mechanics of a Monte Carlo simulation in financial modeling
problems.question: A financial analyst uses a Monte Carlo simulation with 10,000 iterations to value a complex derivative. What does each iteration represent, and how is the final output derived?

choices.A: Each iteration tests a different mathematical formula; the final output is the formula that produces the highest value
choices.B: Each iteration generates one possible price path for the underlying asset by drawing from a probability distribution; the final value is the average discounted payoff across all 10,000 paths
choices.C: Each iteration represents one year of historical price data; the output is the average historical return
choices.D: Each iteration applies a different discount rate; the final output is the value that is most robust across rate assumptions

solution_steps: In Monte Carlo simulation, each iteration draws random numbers from a specified distribution to simulate one possible future path of the underlying asset
For 10,000 iterations, you get 10,000 simulated price paths, each producing a different payoff for the derivative
The present value is estimated by averaging all simulated payoffs and discounting at the risk-free rate

The law of large numbers ensures that as iterations increase, the simulated average converges to the true expected value — Monte Carlo is especially useful for path-dependent options that lack closed-form solutions

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Identify the five inputs to the Black-Scholes option pricing model
problems.question: The Black-Scholes model requires five inputs to price a European call option. Which set of inputs is correct?

choices.A: Current stock price, strike price, beta, dividend yield, and time to maturity
choices.B: Current stock price, strike price, risk-free rate, time to maturity, and volatility of the underlying asset
choices.C: Earnings per share, P/E ratio, growth rate, dividend yield, and volatility
choices.D: Current stock price, book value, debt level, interest rate, and market capitalization

solution_steps: The five Black-Scholes inputs are: S (current stock price), K (strike price), r (risk-free rate), T (time to expiration), and σ (volatility)
Together these determine the probability that the option will expire in-the-money and the present value of the payoff
Beta (systematic risk) is not an input — Black-Scholes works under risk-neutral pricing, which abstracts away from the specific risk preferences of investors
A modified version (Merton model) incorporates continuous dividends as a sixth input for dividend-paying stocks

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Distinguish between historical volatility and implied volatility and explain the significance of the difference
problems.question: A stock has a historical (realized) volatility of 18% over the past year. The implied volatility derived from its at-the-money options is currently 30%. What does this divergence indicate?

choices.A: The stock's options are underpriced because historical volatility is lower than implied volatility
choices.B: The market expects significantly higher future volatility than has been observed historically, possibly due to an anticipated earnings announcement, merger, or macro event
choices.C: The Black-Scholes model is producing incorrect outputs because it cannot handle gaps between historical and implied volatility
choices.D: The divergence means historical volatility is unreliable and should be discarded in favor of implied volatility for all purposes

solution_steps: Implied volatility is forward-looking — it is extracted from current option prices and reflects the market's collective expectation of future price variability
Historical volatility is backward-looking — it measures actual past price dispersion
When implied > historical, the market is pricing in more future uncertainty than the recent past would suggest — common ahead of major events
The VIX index (the 'fear gauge') is the most well-known measure of implied volatility on the S&P 500, and spikes during periods of market stress

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Connect the random walk hypothesis to the Efficient Market Hypothesis and geometric Brownian motion
problems.question: The Geometric Brownian Motion (GBM) model for stock prices assumes that log-returns are independently and identically distributed. Which financial theory does this most directly support?

choices.A: The dividend discount model, because prices grow at a constant rate equal to g
choices.B: The Efficient Market Hypothesis, because if prices follow a random walk, past prices carry no information useful for predicting future prices
choices.C: The trade-off theory of capital structure, because random price movements create unpredictable borrowing costs
choices.D: The CAPM, because GBM generates returns that are proportional to an asset's beta

solution_steps: If stock prices follow a random walk (i.e., changes are independent), then no amount of chart reading or historical analysis can predict future price movements
This is exactly what the weak form of the Efficient Market Hypothesis claims
GBM formalizes this intuition mathematically: dS = μS·dt + σS·dW, where dW is a Wiener process (random increment)
The drift term μ represents the expected return (like the CAPM expected return), but the random term σdW ensures that actual returns cannot be predicted from history alone

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Explain the relationship between the number of simulation paths and the precision of a Monte Carlo estimate
problems.question: A Monte Carlo simulation with 1,000 paths estimates an option value of $8.42 with a standard error of $0.35. The analyst doubles the paths to 2,000. What happens to the standard error of the estimate?

choices.A: The standard error halves to approximately $0.175
choices.B: The standard error is reduced by a factor of √2 to approximately $0.247
choices.C: The standard error stays the same because doubling paths does not improve precision
choices.D: The standard error doubles to $0.70 because more paths introduce more variability

solution_steps: The standard error of a Monte Carlo estimate is proportional to σ / √N, where N is the number of simulation paths
Doubling N from 1,000 to 2,000 multiplies √N by √2 ≈ 1.414

To halve the standard error (Option A), you would need to quadruple the number of paths (4,000), not double them — this is the key insight about Monte Carlo convergence: precision improves slowly with additional paths

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Interpret option delta as both a sensitivity measure and a probability proxy
problems.question: A European call option on a stock has a delta of 0.65. Which of the following best interprets this number?

choices.A: The option will expire in-the-money with 65% probability, and the option's price will increase by approximately $0.65 for every $1 increase in the stock price
choices.B: The option requires a hedge ratio of 65% — to replicate it, you must borrow 65% of the stock's value
choices.C: The option will lose 65% of its value for every 1% decline in the underlying stock price
choices.D: The option's premium represents 65% of its intrinsic value at the current stock price

solution_steps: Delta (Δ) is the partial derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying stock price: Δ = ∂C/∂S
A delta of 0.65 means the option price increases by approximately $0.65 for every $1 rise in the stock price
Under risk-neutral pricing in the Black-Scholes framework, delta also approximates the probability that the option expires in-the-money (N(d1) in Black-Scholes notation)
Delta ranges from 0 to 1 for calls (and -1 to 0 for puts): deep in-the-money calls approach delta=1 (move nearly 1:1 with the stock); deep out-of-the-money calls approach delta=0

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Evaluate the practical consequences of using thin-tailed models in a fat-tailed financial world
problems.question: A risk manager uses a VaR model assuming normally distributed daily returns with σ = 1%. The model predicts that a loss greater than 2.33% (a 2.33-sigma event) should occur on only 1% of trading days. In reality, such losses occur roughly 3–4% of the time. What is the best explanation for this discrepancy?

choices.A: The risk manager made a calculation error in setting σ = 1%; the correct value should be 2%
choices.B: The normal distribution underestimates the frequency of large losses because real return distributions have fat tails — extreme events are far more common than the normal model predicts
choices.C: VaR is only accurate for horizons longer than one month; daily VaR is inherently unreliable regardless of distribution assumptions
choices.D: The discrepancy indicates that the stock market is trending upward and the model needs a drift adjustment

solution_steps: Empirical return distributions exhibit excess kurtosis (fat tails) — the tails are thicker than those of a normal distribution
This means extreme outcomes are not as rare as normal-distribution models suggest, which is why '100-year floods' in finance seem to happen every decade
The normal distribution is a simplifying assumption made for mathematical tractability, not because it accurately describes reality in the tails
Post-2008 risk management increasingly uses fat-tailed distributions (Student's t, historical simulation, extreme value theory) and stress tests rather than relying solely on VaR

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Apply core TVM concepts to a real-world financial planning context
problems.question: A company needs to accumulate $1,000,000 in 10 years to fund a plant replacement. It can invest at 7% per year. How much must it deposit as a lump sum today?
solution_steps: This is a straightforward present value calculation — the answer illustrates how TVM quantifies capital planning decisions across time

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Identify how information flows between the three core financial statements
problems.question: Net income from the income statement appears in which other financial statement, and in what context?

choices.A: The balance sheet, as a direct addition to the cash account
choices.B: Both the cash flow statement (as the starting point for operating cash flow under the indirect method) and the balance sheet (as an addition to retained earnings in shareholders' equity)
choices.C: Only the cash flow statement, as a reconciling item between beginning and ending cash
choices.D: The balance sheet only, as an addition to paid-in capital under the stockholders' equity section

solution_steps: Net income is the primary link between the income statement and the other two statements
On the cash flow statement (indirect method), net income is the starting point — non-cash items and working capital changes are then added or subtracted to arrive at operating cash flow
On the balance sheet, net income (less dividends paid) increases retained earnings, which is a component of shareholders' equity
This three-statement linkage is the foundation of integrated financial modeling — a change in any assumption propagates across all three statements simultaneously

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Recall the purpose of WACC and connect it to the valuation frameworks studied in the course
problems.question: In a DCF valuation, WACC is used as the discount rate when discounting FCFF. What does this choice of discount rate imply about whose cash flows you are valuing?

choices.A: You are valuing only the equity holders' share of cash flows, so the result is directly the stock price
choices.B: You are valuing the cash flows attributable to all capital providers (debt and equity), so the result is enterprise value — net debt must then be subtracted to reach equity value
choices.C: You are valuing the firm's assets at historical cost, as reported on the balance sheet
choices.D: You are discounting at the risk-free rate, implying no risk premium is applied to the free cash flows

solution_steps: FCFF belongs to all capital providers — it is the cash generated before making interest payments or principal repayments to debt holders
Discounting FCFF at WACC (the blended required return of all capital providers) yields the Enterprise Value of the firm
To arrive at equity value, subtract net debt (total debt minus cash) from enterprise value
This chain — FCFF → WACC → EV → minus net debt → equity value → divided by shares → price per share — is the complete DCF valuation workflow

problems.question: A stock just paid a dividend of $2.50 (D0). Dividends grow at 4% per year. The risk-free rate is 3%, the market risk premium is 6%, and the stock's beta is 1.1. What is the stock's intrinsic value using the Gordon Growth Model?

Step 2 — Calculate D1: D1 = $2.50 × 1.04 = $2.60

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Use WACC to evaluate whether a project creates value, integrating capital structure analysis with investment decision-making
problems.question: A firm has 60% equity (cost = 11%) and 40% debt (pre-tax cost = 7%, tax rate = 30%). A proposed project is expected to return 8.5%. Should the firm accept the project?

choices.A: Yes — the project return of 8.5% is positive, so it always creates value
choices.B: No — after calculating WACC at 8.38%, the project return of 8.5% barely exceeds WACC and may not provide sufficient margin of safety
choices.C: Yes — 8.5% exceeds the after-tax cost of debt (4.9%), so the project is profitable from the debtholders' perspective
choices.D: No — the project return of 8.5% is below the cost of equity (11%), so equity holders would be better off with their capital returned

solution_steps: After-tax cost of debt = 7% × (1 - 0.30) = 4.9%
Project return of 8.5% < WACC of 8.56% → technically NPV < 0 → marginally reject
Option B correctly identifies the narrow margin; in practice, both the marginal NPV and model uncertainty around inputs would inform the final decision

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Apply financial crisis concepts to evaluate the vulnerability of a hypothetical leveraged financial institution
problems.question: A hedge fund holds $500 million in assets financed by $475 million in short-term repo debt and $25 million in equity. Asset values decline 6% due to a market shock. Which combination of problems does the fund face?

choices.A: The fund faces minor liquidity pressure but remains solvent because the decline is less than 10%
choices.B: The fund is immediately insolvent (equity wiped out) and faces a liquidity crisis as repo lenders demand repayment, forcing fire-sale asset liquidations that further depress prices — a classic liquidity spiral
choices.C: The fund is solvent but must immediately increase its equity base to comply with leverage regulations
choices.D: The fund faces a temporary mark-to-market loss but will recover as markets normalize, because repo lenders will extend credit given the fund's strong track record

solution_steps: Step 1 — Solvency check: 6% × $500M = $30M loss; equity was only $25M → assets ($470M) < debt ($475M) → insolvent
Step 2 — Liquidity problem: short-term repo lenders will not roll over debt for an insolvent counterparty; they demand repayment
Step 3 — Fire sale spiral: the fund must sell assets to repay repo, pushing prices down further, worsening losses for itself and other holders of similar assets
This scenario mirrors the LTCM collapse and describes the classic liquidity spiral: insolvency + short-term funding + illiquid assets = systemic feedback loop

problems.subject: Finance
problems.subtopic: Capital Structure Decision Under Real Constraints
problems.learning_objective: Evaluate a capital structure decision by simultaneously considering WACC, financial distress risk, and NPV
problems.question: A firm currently has no debt and a WACC of 12% (equal to its cost of equity). It is considering issuing $50M in debt at 7% (tax rate 25%) to partially fund a $100M project expected to return 10%. The new debt would bring D/E to 1.0. What integrated analysis should guide this decision?

choices.A: Accept — the project return of 10% exceeds the cost of debt of 7%, so issuing debt and investing is clearly value-creating
choices.B: Reject — adding debt always increases risk, so the all-equity hurdle rate of 12% should remain the benchmark regardless of capital structure changes
choices.C: The decision requires comparing the project's NPV using the revised WACC with the tax shield benefit weighed against increased financial distress risk — simply comparing to either rate alone ignores the capital structure interaction
choices.D: Accept — under Modigliani-Miller with taxes, any amount of debt strictly increases firm value through the tax shield, so the firm should always lever up to fund positive-return projects

solution_steps: The revised WACC after issuing debt: equity weight = 50%, debt weight = 50%; Re (assume stays ~12%), Rd_aftertax = 7%×0.75 = 5.25%; WACC = 0.5×12% + 0.5×5.25% = 8.625%
At the new WACC of 8.625%, the project return of 10% > WACC → positive NPV → value-creating
However, D/E of 1.0 is material leverage — financial distress costs and loss of financial flexibility must also be evaluated (trade-off theory)
Option D overstates MM: the no-distress-cost assumption breaks down at high leverage; Option A ignores the equity holders' perspective; Option B ignores the tax shield benefit of debt

problems.subject: Finance
problems.learning_objective: Synthesize stochastic modeling, valuation, and crisis analysis to evaluate a portfolio manager's decision during a market stress event
problems.question: A portfolio manager holds a concentrated position in a single leveraged financial institution. The manager's DCF model shows the stock is 20% undervalued, her Monte Carlo simulation assigns only a 5% probability to insolvency, and the firm has a D/E ratio of 8.0. Implied volatility has just spiked from 20% to 60%. What is the most comprehensive assessment of her position?

choices.A: The position is attractive — DCF undervaluation of 20% is a compelling buy signal, and 95% solvency probability confirms manageable risk
choices.B: The implied volatility spike signals that the market has dramatically repriced tail risk; the DCF likely underestimates distress costs at D/E=8, the Monte Carlo may be using thin-tailed assumptions, and concentration in a leveraged financial firm during a stress event compounds all three risks simultaneously
choices.C: The manager should sell immediately because implied volatility above 50% always signals imminent default for financial companies
choices.D: The position requires no action — DCF and Monte Carlo are more rigorous than market signals like implied volatility, and the manager should trust her fundamental analysis

solution_steps: Each data point in isolation looks manageable — but together they tell a coherent stress scenario warning
A D/E of 8.0 means equity is an extremely thin buffer: a 12.5% decline in asset value wipes out equity entirely — precisely the leverage amplification risk studied in the crises chapter
The DCF likely uses normalized cash flows that do not incorporate a financial distress scenario; at D/E=8, distress costs are non-trivial and should be probability-weighted

The Monte Carlo's 5% insolvency estimate is only as reliable as its distribution assumption — if it uses a normal distribution, it will drastically understate tail probabilities in a fat-tailed stress environment (the lesson from the L109 fat tails question)

The implied volatility spike from 20% to 60% is the market's real-time collective judgment that uncertainty has tripled — ignoring it in favor of a model built on pre-stress assumptions is precisely the kind of model-vs-market disconnect that characterized risk management failures in 2008
